section.name: Installing the useradmin sample
section.p: Installing the useradmin sample is a simple task. The useradmin sample can be found in the useradmin distribution or the full distribution genesis packages that can be found here. Distributions for all samples are already setup to be run in standalone/local mode or with the JBoss application server, an open-source free server. This does not mean genesis only runs on this server; genesis was developed in a J2EE compatible way.
Ant is required to run the useradmin sample. To run this sample in remote mode, it's the JBoss application server is also required.
Learn how to run this sample in local mode (without an application server) here.
Learn how to run this sample in remote mode (using an application server) here.
To use the SWT portion of useradmin's sample, read the instructions here.

section.name: useradmin sample's purpose
section.p: useradmin sample's purpose is to demonstrate to users genesis' major features and also is a great example of transparent remoting in action, since with the same source code, it's possible to run the sample using either remote or local calls.

The sample has two source code dirs, <GENESIS_DIST>/samples/useradmin/modules/client/src and <GENESIS_DIST>/samples/useradmin/modules/shared/src, that contain the client module and the client/server shared module, respectively.
The client module source dir contains UI related classes. The useradmin sample uses three different UI technologies: Thinlet, Swing and SWT. To use SWT, read the instructions here.

The package net.java.dev.genesis.samples.useradmin.ui contains files that define the UI logic (rules to enable and disable fields, actions, etc). We call these classes forms and they are independent of UI technology. For example, UserListForm.java it's a Java class whose fields represent screen data e it has methods that represent screen actions.
At Thinlet (package net.java.dev.genesis.samples.useradmin.ui.thinlet) we found two file types that define the UI. Let's consider the useradmin search screen:

ul.li: user-list.xml: Thinlet xml file that describes how UI components are arranged on the screen. Component names match field names and method names in the form.

UserListView.java: Java class responsible for the screen, where the UI dimensions are defined, which UI xml file to use and that binds a form to a view. Other auxiliary methods may be defined by this class in order to allow other screens to be open or to programatically invoke a form action.

section.p: At Swing (package net.java.dev.genesis.samples.useradmin.ui.swing and sub-packages) we found the UI skeleton coded using Swing. Let's consider the useradmin search screen:

ul.li: UserListView.java: Java class coded using Swing and responsible for the search screen, where the UI dimensions are defined and how UI components are arranged on the screen. The binding with a specific form is done, that means that the form will handle the UI events. Other auxiliary methods are defined to make possible other windows to be opened and programatically call some action of this screen.

section.p: At SWT (package net.java.dev.genesis.samples.useradmin.ui.swt and sub-packages) we found the UI skeleton coded using SWT. Let's consider the useradmin search screen:

ul.li: UserListView.java: Java class coded using SWT and responsible for the search screen, where the UI dimensions are defined and how UI components are arranged on the screen. The binding with a specific form is done, that means that the form will handle the UI events. Other auxiliary methods are defined to make possible other windows to be opened and programatically call some action of this screen.

section.p: The shared module source dir contains the source files that implement business logic (commands) and others that are Hibernate mapped classes (databeans). A command example is net.java.dev.genesis.samples.useradmin.business.UserCreateCommand :

This example shows how simple and straight commands can be. The command shown above has just a transactional method that persists a user in the database. Transaction commit/rollback is automatically hanlded by genesis.

A databean is JavaBean compliant class, i.e., one that exposes properties through getters and setters. It doesn't have to implement any interface nor to extend any abstract class. It is convenient to implement java.io.Serializable so the class can be used as a parameter or as a return value for a remote call.

section.name: Running in local mode
section.p: To run this sample in local mode, you will need:

ul.li: The Ant tool, prefer the latest version (currently Ant 1.6.5)

section.p: Follow the steps:

ul.li: Make a copy of buid.properties.sample file and rename to build.properties
Edit the build.properties file, modifying or commenting the properties according your needs. Take a look on a configuration sample:
ul.source:
## Build properties sample ##
# Here we defined that it won't run in remote mode remote.mode=false
# In local mode, a database is needed. In this case, we use HSQLDB jdbc.driver=target/hsqldb.jar
ul.li:
In command line, executes the ant script:
c:\genesis\samples\useradmin>ant install
This command will start the installation process. It will only copy all dependant libraries to the folder where the application jar resides.

section.name: Running in remote mode
section.p: To run this sample in remote mode, you will need:

ul.li: The Ant tool, prefer the latest version (currently Ant 1.6.5)
The JBoss Application Server, prefer the latest version of the series 3.2.x or 4.0.x

section.p: To run this sample in remote mode, follow the steps:

ul.li: Make a copy of buid.properties.sample file and rename to build.properties
Edit the build.properties file, modifying or commenting the properties according your needs. Take a look on a configuration sample:
ul.source:
## Build properties sample ##
# Here we defined that it won't run in local mode local.mode=false
# Here we define the JBoss Home directory jboss.home=/opt/jboss-3.2.7
ul.li:
In the command line, run the ant script:
c:\genesis\samples\useradmin>ant install
The installation process will start and a folder called "useradmin" will be created at the server folder of JBoss Application Server. That folder contains the useradmin sample, its configuration and all of its dependencies.
After the installation process, start JBoss with the following command:

After JBoss starts, the sample can be executed accessing the URL
http://localhost:8080/useradmin/. The " Run remote User Admin" link will download, install and run the sample on the user machine, with Java Web Start technology

If you have left local mode enabled, you can run the sample in local mode throught the link "Run local User Admin" of http://localhost:8080/useradmin/ page.

section.name: Considerations
section.p: This sample goal is to demonstrate how a project might be structured and how to use genesis features. It's recommended to start new genesis- based projects by using the empty project as a start point and use this sample as a refenrece.
